div.head: THE SUAKIN EXPEDITIONARY FORCE.
div.p: Major General Sir G. Graham, V.C., K.C.B., and his Head Quarter Staff left the Capital for Suez by special train last night at eleven o'clock.

Major General Davis left yesterday evening for Suakin for employment with the Expeditiouary Force, should his services be necessary. It is feared at the Horse Guards that Colonel Sir R. Buller will not reach Egypt in time.

Captain Baynes of the Cameron Highlanders has been appointed Assistant Military Secretary and Lieutenant F. W. Romilly of the Scots Guards and W. A. Scott of the Cameron Highlanders have been appointed aides-de-camp on the Staff of the Major General Commanding the Force.
During the temporary absence of General Davis Colonel Leith, C.B., of the Cameron Highlanders, will assume command of the troops at Cairo and Abbasseeyeh.

Lieutenant J. T. St. Aubyn of the Grenadier Guards has been appointed to act as aide-de-camp to Colonel Sir R. Buller, V.C.C.B., K.C.M.G. commanding the infantry of the ... of the 1st Royal Dragoons has been appointed aide-de-camp to Colonel H. Stewart commanding the cavalry of the Force.

It appears that General Lord Wolseley is directing the whole of the details of the expedition to Tokar from the Horse Guards. His Lordship has sent particular instructions that the affair is not to take more than three weeks, within which time all the troops are to be back in Cairo.
Large numbers of camels for the Force have been requisitioned in several districts by the local authorities.

The authorities have succeeded in obtaining all the camel drivers that are to accompany the British expedition to the Soudan: 140 of these have volunteered from the Egyptian Army and 150 were collected at Zagazig.
Major Forster of the Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry will be attached to the Commissariat and Transport Corps with a view to his being in charge of the mules which accompany the Force.

Lieutenants C. C. Douglas of the Cameron Highlanders and Turner of the Shropshire Light Infantry have been appointed to do duty with the Commissariat and Transport Corps Staff, accompanying the Force.
Lieutenant Riddell of the King's Royal Rifle Corps who was temporarily attached to the Egyptian Army hus rejoined his battalion for duty.
Lieutenant W. Lloyd of the Royal Horse Artillery has been temporarily attached to the 19th Hussars.
Interpreter Michael Boulos Kouri has been attached to the 20th Company of Royal Engineers at the pay of 10s per day and rations.

Interpreter F. Vella proceeds with the Force as interpreter to the Ordnance Store Department and Mr. William Balcher goes as interpreter to the Senior Commissarist Officer, both these interpreters being paid at the rate of 10s. per day and rations.

Two complete field hospitals of 200 beds each are coming out from England: One is to be stationed at Suez and the other at Suakin. There will also be a dieted hospital on the vessel which will ply between Suakin and Suez.
The only wheeled transport that will be used in the expedition will be the water-carts and ambulances.
Interpreter Abdulla Mattar has proceeded with the Force to Suakin as interpreter to the Principal Medical Officer.
The Decree reorgainsing the Sanitary and Hygienic Administrations in Egypt was officially promulgated on the 16th instant.
Sir Evelyn Baring continues very unwell. He was able to attend an Extraordinary Council that assembled at his residence yesterday afternoon at two o'clock, and went to bed immediately afterwards.

H. M. S. Téméraire flying the flag of Vice-Admiral Lord John Hay, K.C.B, Commander-in-Chief of the Mediterranean Squadron, arrived off the harbour this morning. Shortly after her arrival his Lordship transferred his flag to H.M.S. Invincible and the customary salutes were fired.
The Téméraire will leave for Port-Said to-day as well as the chartered transport, Northumbria.
His Excelleney Osman Pasha Orphy, Governor of Alexandria, and Mustapha Pasha el-Arab, Deputy Minister of Marine, paid an official visit this morning to the British Admiral.
A party of blue jackets was landed this morning for duty on shore in Alexandria.
During the absence of Lieutenant J. T. St. Aubyn Captain Maberly, R A., has been appointed to act temporarily as aide-do-camp to Major General Earle, C.B., C.S.I.

General Gordon Pasha telegraphs to the Government from Shendy, respecting details which are of no general interest. He continues to be in high spirits, and has no doubt as to the success of his mission.

Our local contemporaries have called attention to an incident that occurred at the Italian Circus at Cairo on Thursday evening, in which a British officer was concerned. The officer had left for Suez, en route for Suakin, before the matter had come to the knowledge of the Lieut.-General Commanding the Army of Occupation. He has since been recalled, under arrest, and will be dealt with in accordance with the system of military discipline that is in force in the British Army.

The incident is deeply to be regretted, but we must not forget that allowance must be made for the very natural excitement of both officers and men on the eve of entering upon a campaign. We may assure our sister colonies that the culprit had not the slightest intention of offering any insult to any nationality whatever and we confidently appeal to the general behaviour of both officers and men of the Army of Occupation in support of our espression of regret that anything, however trivial, should have occurred calculated...existing between the Army of Occupation and the different communities in Egypt.

The annual ball in aid of the Greek Hospital will take place on Tuesday the 26th inst. and, judging from what we hear of the preparations already being made, the Fete will be as brilliant, perhaps more so than in previons years; for no pains, expense or forethought will be spared to render it a perfect success.

The Greek Community of Alexandria have chosen two gentlemen to make the necessary arrangements for the organization of the ball and their selection appears to us a very happy one. The gentlemen chosen are M. T. Sinadino and Mr. E. A. Benachi.

It would perhaps not be amiss if we mentioned a few of the leading features in connection with the admirable Institution on behalf of which the ball is given. Although it is known under the denomination of the "Greek Hospital" it is practically an international one, being open to patients of every nationality--rich or poor--the majority of the out-door patients being natives, numbering no less, on an average, than two hundred a day. The hospital is supported by the Greek Community, aided by many Greeks residing in different parts of the world and its funds are supplemented to a certain extent by the donations of many philanthropic outsiders who appreciate the value of such an Institution,

The present building was opened in the early part of 1882 and escaped pillage and burning during the sad events of June and July of the same year, by the lucky chance that Araby had sent up some of his sick and wounded to be cared for there.

It is to be regretted that only one half of this Splendid edifice is finished, the completion of the other half (although most necessary) has had to remain in abeyance for want of funds, and what is still more to be deplored is, that the part at present in use and doing such good service does not cover the expenditure, owing to so many free patients having to be received; this is caused by the general stagnntion of trade and the misery which unfortunately prevails in Alexandria.

The Hospital is fortunate in having such able physicians as Drs. Zancarol, Moschatos and Kartulis, who are, according to all accounts, indefatigable in their endeavours to alleviate the sufferings of the patients.

The internal maragement of the Institution is confided to Mrs. Nicholas, the Lady Superintendent, who is assisted by a staff of experienced English sisters, and it is almost unnecessary to say that the unremitting kindness these ladies display towards patients of all classes has become proverbial.

In putting these few main facts before our readers we feel convinced they will respond to our call and assist such an excellent institution, the more so, that, as we have already stated, it is open to patients of every creed, nationality and race---philanthropy is the only object the promoters have in view.

We may add that tickets for the ball can be obtained, and donations on behalf of the Hospital will be received at the Offices of Messrs Sinadino Ralli & Co. and Messrs Choremi Benachi & Co., Alexandria.

The recent unusually wet weather which has prevailed throughout the Delta is reported as having seriously delayed the tillage for cotton sowing: the land is said to be so saturated with moisture that, for the present, it cannot be prepared to receive the seed.

We trust, however, that attention having been drawn to the matter we shall not again be under the painful necessity of referring to similar cases of natives being maltreated by persons who, from their position, might be expected to set a better example to the community. In any case the Consular Courts will, we feel assured, give satisfaction to any native who may wish to obtain redress for any wrong done to him.

div.head: BASHA FELLAKA ON ABYSSINIA.
div.p: … dining sallon at Shepheard's Hotel, Captain Speedy, the Basha Fellaka of Abyssinia, delivered an exceedingly interesting lecture upon that country and the habits and customs of its inhabitants before a considerable audience of ladies and gentlemen. The proceeds of the lecture were for the benefit of Welba Haimanot, an Ethiopian youth. The entertainment comprised a description of modern Ethiopia, the religion of the country, King Theodore's Camp, an Abyssinian Priest, Warrior, Citizen, Lawsuits, modes of wearing the Shammah, a marriage ceremony and the story of the fall, of Magdala.

The lecturer commenced by relating the conversion of the Abyssinians to Christianity in A. D. 313. Two monks from Alexandria: Frumentius and Eudoceas were wrecked at Massawa and carried captive to the Abyssinian monarch, in whose service they remained till the death of their master, A. D. 324. Eudoceus died on the voyage back, but Frumentius reported his return to Bishop Athanasius, who ordained him Bishop of Axum, the northern metropolis of Ethiopia. Thither Frumentius returned in A. D. 325 and in 5 years, owing to his labours, Ethiopia or rather Habesha (its modern name) became Christian. Nothing further was known to Europe of this country till the end of the 13th century--an interval of nearly 1000 years.

At that time Prince Henry of Portugal being extremely anxious to discover the mythical Christian monarch "Prester John," despatched two emissaries to Asia, for that purpose. After years of fruitless travel one of them returned to Europe but the other, Pedro Covilhan, happening to call at the port of Massawa, formerly belonging to Abyssinia, heard of a powerful Christian monarch in the interior, and persuading himself that this must be the object of his search, he penetrated the country, where all he saw and heard confirmed his belief that he had really succeeded in his quest. After a few years sojourn at the Court of the Abyssinian King. Pedro returned to Portugal to assure the Prince Henry that the veritable "Prester John" had been discovered.

Abyssinia professes the Coptic form of the Christian faith. Priests can marry, but only once. No sculptures are permitted in their Churches, only painting. The Churches are circular and divided into outer and inner courts, with a Kedusa Kedusan, a Holy of Holies, in the centre.

Their Scriptures are similar to ours, but they admit the Apocrypha. The Song of Solomon they take literally, and believe it to have been written by King Solomon in honour of the Queen of Sheba. -- "I am black but comely, Oh! ye daughters of Jerusalem" seeming to the Abyssinians an absolute proof of the fact.

The lecturer next gave a short sketch of his travels in Abyssinia during 1861 and 1862, describing his residence at the Court of King Theodore. He imitated the remarkable drum langange of Abyssinia which forms a strange and curious feature of the military discipline of the country, Jah Hoi, Jan Hoi, Hail to His Majesty. Gibbarer igba &c. &c.

The lecturer said that Theodore was a man of 5 ft. 10 in. in height, muscular, dark complexioned, aquiline nose, and with eyes of unusual brilliancy. A man of great abilities, brave, generous and true to his word, with a strange mixture of excessive pride and deep humility. After refusing every inducement to enter the King's service, Besha Fellaka (as Captain Speedy is known in Abyssinia) was permitted to leave the country. The King asked him when he intended to start, on receiving the reply tomorrow Theodore exclaimed: " Go now, to-morrow I may change my mind."

The lecturer then retired, to change his dress and returned as an Abyssinian Priest chaunting a hymn in Ethiopic; he next read a Psalm, afterwards represented a warrior and then a citizen, illustrating the various modes of wearing the Shammah or Abyssinian toga, the graceful folds of which were much admired; he went through the marriage ceremony which elicited much laughter. The evening's entertainment, which was an extremely pleasant and interesting one, concluded with a short account of the capture of Magdala.

div.head: PUBLIC FEELING IN ENGLAND.
div.p: The Pall Mall Gasette which, as most of our readers are aware, is a supporter of the Party at present in power thus expresses itself on the subject of the present state of public feeling at home:

The country has stood the massacre of a few hundreds within a day's march of our ships --- it may not mind the slaughter of a few thousands more in the heart of the Soudan. To save them might be dangerous, and would certainly be expensive. Only, however, let Ministers be under no delusion as to one thing. Do not let them delude themselves by the notion that the anxiety to which the metropolitan press has given expression is confined to London. It is even more strongly expressed in the country. If "the metropolitan press has gone mad," the malady is shared by most of the provincial journals. We may supplement our remarks by saying that dissatisfaction with the indefinite prolongation of the policy of half hearted refusal to recognise responsibility has been nowhere expressed more significantly than by the great Liberal organs of Leeds, Manchester, Liverpool, Dundee, and Glasgow. On the whole, seeing how public opinion is going, probably the least the Government can do is to despatch with as little delay as possible those reinforcements which are ready to be sent to Alexandria the moment the order is given. It may be precipitate, but undue precipitancy has hardly been the besetting sin of the Government in dealing with the Soudan,

div.head: MR. GOSCHEN ON EGYPTIAN AFFAIRS.
div.p: Mr. Goschen, M.P., speaking at a dinner on the 1st inst. at Ripon, contended that members of Parliament ought never to be pleased at the misfortunes of their political opponents if, as the result of such misfortune, … should happen to the public weal, and, proceeding to ask what were the wishes of Europe with regard to the difficulties in which we found ourselves in Egypt, he said there were not only English interests concerned, there were European interests at stake, and there were humanitarian interests, because the Soodan was the home of the slave trader. He trusted that no event would happen which would make Europe think that because there were difficulties in the way, England would flinch from the continued efforts which she had always made for the suppression of that infamous traffic. It was a matter of comparative indifference to Europe whether the Arabs or the Turks held the Soodan: in fact, it might be that it was more for the interest of Europe that Arabs should hold the Soodan than that Turks or Egyptians should hold it. Europe knew that she had interests in Egypt, and was calling upon us to discharge them; still, there was some talk of keeping us to our pledges of disinterested action, and there was still more talk of the necessity that we should perform those duties in Egypt which by our position we had undertaken, and the fulfillment of which was of great interest to all European communities in Egypt. That langauge was held in the European Press. Well, then, he thought that the other countries of Europe, at all events, could be called upon to render such assistance as the circumstances permit; and there was one piece of assistance which foreign Governments could render us in this matter. He referred to the Law of Liquidation.

Now this Law of Liquidation stood in the way of the necessary means being found to carry on the warlike operations, unless the money could be found by what was impossible--further taxes in Egypt. And if other foreign countries expressed themselves so concerned as to our fulfilling our liabilities and duties in Egypt, they ought to consent, and ought to be asked to consent to the suspension of this Law of Liquidation, so that the finances might be put on the footing which the circumstances required. France, above all, should be approached from this point of view. He somewhat criticised the disposition shown by the French Press in this matter, and submitted that, considering the French commerce and the French lives that might be at stake, the time had come when we might fairly say to France, " Untie our hands. If we are supreme in Egypt, and you look to our supremacy to help you, assist us in your turn by consenting to this change in the Law of Liquidation, which is necessary for the good of Egypt, for the finances of Egypt, and for the proper conduct of business in the present circumstances of the case." He concluded with some observations on the general armaments of Europe and their pressure upon the nations. Europe, he remarked, still remained an armed camp, though he believed that all the Great Powers were sincerely desirous of peace. But he might not be cynical when he expressed his further belief that they were desirous for peace, because they thought that wars at the present moment would be exceedingly inconvenient.

div.head: Feuilleton de l'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Perdus au fond des chemins sombres du bois, les deux amis laissèrent deborder leur coeur sans contrainte. Les heures fuyaient sans qu'ils s'en aperçussent. Henri le premier recouvre son sangfroid.
